item.title: Marvel Rivals Ultron Trick Makes Him Shoot Faster
item.description:
Summary

  • Marvel Rivals fans found a trick to make Ultron's beam attack faster by using his melee blade in between shots.
  • The trick is most prominent when cooldowns are turned off in the Practice Range.
  • Some fans appreciate the trick, while others point out it may not be beneficial due to missing burst damage and the effort required.

Marvel Rivals fans have discovered a clever Ultron trick that makes him shoot his beam energy beam faster. Launched in Marvel Rivals Season 2.5, Ultron is the newest Strategist to arrive in the game, combining both healing and the ability to deal significant damage to opponents.

In Marvel Comics lore, Ultron is a powerful AI on a mission to destroy organic life, especially The Avengers. He is mostly known as a destructive character in the comics and even in the Marvel Cinematic Universe (MCU), while also taking the role of antagonist in Marvel Rivals Season 2. Fans initially found it odd that Marvel Rivals gave Ultron the Strategist role, but as a hyper-intelligent AI, Ultron is undoubtedly a strategic genius.

With Ultron officially playable, Marvel Rivals players have been testing him out in the Practice Range before diving into a match. A player named siphagiel would later discover that Ultron can shoot faster if they use his melee blade in between shots. In a short side-by-side video on Reddit, they showed how Ultron's Encephalo-Ray (his main attack) shoots more consistently when they quickly hit a melee attackâ€”a classic animation cancel.

Can Ultron's Melee Attack Really Make His Shots Faster?

However, in another post, siphagiel showed that the melee trick is more prominent when cooldowns are turned off in the Practice Range. Hitting the melee attack doesn't seem to make that much of a difference to Ultron's shooting speed, but the player also claims he shoots 0.65 seconds faster per mag with the trick, which is still a slight improvement.

In the comments, most Marvel Rivals fans were appreciative of the player sharing the melee trick, even if it only makes a small change to Ultron's shooting speed. Some pointed out that switching to another ability to cancel an animation is the same technique that Cloak and Dagger mains use instead of pressing the reload button to replenish Lightforce Daggers. Meanwhile, a few fans also alleged that players who do the melee trick might miss out on the Encephalo-Ray's burst damage at the end, and that it might take more effort to trigger a melee attack than letting the cooldown animation trigger.

Reloading in Marvel Rivals is a touchy topic for many players because the mechanic doesn't make sense with some magic-wielding characters, like Doctor Strange and Storm. Players have called on NetEase Games to consider tweaking this, but it's likely that the developer gave certain characters a reload mechanic for the sake of game balance.

item.title: Elden Ring Nightreign: How To Get Holy Weapons For Tricephalos & Final Boss
item.description:
When taking on Elden Ring Nightreign 's various expeditions, it's important to track down the right tools for the job. Nightreign's first expedition, Tricephalus, bucks a common trend of the original Elden Ring's main bosses by having its main boss be vulnerable to holy damage. This means that bringing ways of dealing holy damage with you on this expedition will make it substantially easier to handle.

Another of Elden Ring Nightreign 's expeditions that is made notably easier with access to holy damage is the final expedition, Night Aspect, whose final boss (and the final boss of the game itself) is particularly weak to holy damage. This guide will explain how to track down holy weapon locations more easily, and offer a suggestion of how to begin an expedition with a weapon dealing holy damage.

How to Find Holy Weapons On the Map in Elden Ring Nightreign

Luckily, you can spot potential Holy Weapon locations on the Map in Nightreign. Unfortunately, the symbol for Holy and the Symbol for Lightning are very similar, so you'll have to look closely to spot the difference on the map. The symbol you're looking for can be seen in image 1, above. These symbols will be found next to any location where weapons that deal that kind of damage can be found.

Players who favor magic could also try using the map's detailed view to locate Sacred Seals, since these will sometimes have spells that deal Holy Damage. This isn't as reliable as the previously mentioned method, but is still a good way of tracking down some more ways of dealing Holy damage if the symbol isn't showing up anywhere on the map.

When going up against the Tricephalos Expedition, or the Night Aspect Expedition, the final boss will be particularly weak to holy damage, so make sure to prioritize any locations with the holy icon when challenging these expeditions.

How to Start an Expedition with a Holy Weapon in Elden Ring Nightreign

Players looking to dish out Holy Damage from the start of the run, or guarantee that they have a Holy Weapon regardless of how the map generation pans out, will need to have a bit of luck with their relics. Certain relics will change the damage type of a character's starting weapon, and if you get one that converts weapons to holy damage, you can start out any run with a holy damage weapon. This will work for any character who can equip the relic, except for the Recluse, as her starting staff's damage is determined by the spell being cast.

item.title: Elden Ring Nightreign: How To Surge Sprint & Wall Climb
item.description:
Elden Ring Nightreign is a fast-paced rogue-like title that puts players on a timer to prepare themselves during the day to fight a powerful boss by night. Due to the verticality of the Limveld's map, players receive two new types of movement abilities: Surge Sprinting and Wall Climbing. By combining these abilities, players can dash as fast as the Spirit Steed Torrent and scale the tallest cliffs with ease. Here's how these new abilities work.

How to Surge Sprint in Elden Ring Nightreign

Surge Sprinting is an enhanced version of the regular dash ability that increases the player's mobility and allows them to cover great distances with speed in Elden Ring Nightreign . It's also a great tool in combat if used right, as you'll be able to escape AOE attacks from enemies or position yourself at an advantageous point.

However, Surge Sprint is a double-edged sword, as it quickly depletes stamina if used in combat . So, it's recommended that players use a combination of regular dashing and surge sprinting in combat to optimize stamina usage. Otherwise, there won't be any left to land hits on the enemies.

Here's how to use the Dash and Surge Sprint in ER Nightreign .

Platform

Dash

Surge Sprint

Keyboard (PC)

Press and hold the "Shift" key

Press the "ALT" key to toggle

Xbox Controller

Press and hold the "B" button

Press "Left Stick" to toggle

PlayStation Controller

Press and hold the "O" button

Press "L3" to toggle.

How to Wall Climb in Nightreign

Wall jumping is another new mobility skill added to Elden Ring Nightreign that makes traversing vertical levels easier and quicker . Players will need to simply approach either an easily climbable ledge or a vertical surface lined with tombstones. Make sure to jump towards an easy-to-reach area, so the character can easily ledge grab and vault it.

The mechanic can be a little weird at times , as it sometimes lets you scale walls, and sometimes the character refuses to grab the ledge. So, you'll need to do some practice before mastering this new traversal mechanic in Nightreign .

Here's how to perform Wall Jumps to scale vertical surfaces in ER Nightreign .

Platform

Wall Jump/Climb

Keyboard (PC)

Double-press the "Space Bar" near a scalable wall

Xbox Controller

Double-press the "A" button near a scalable wall

PlayStation Controller

Press and hold the "O" button near a scalable wall

item.title: All 126 Monsters in Fantasy Life i & Where to Find Them
item.description:
Finding rare materials is an important part of Fantasy Life i: The Girl Who Steals Time , especially once players have completed the main story and moved on to postgame grinding. Most basic materials can be obtained from common monsters in Fantasy Life i , but rare materials required to craft the strongest recipes can only be obtained from rare boss enemies that only show up under certain conditions.

The islands of the past that players visit throughout the main story of Fantasy Life i are home to most of the game's monsters, but a few monsters are exclusive to Treasure Groves or high-rank Ginormosia regions. Treasure Groves are entirely random, though, and increasing area ranks in Ginormosia is a huge grind. You don't want to waste your time in the wrong place if you're after a specific material, so it's a good idea to familiarize yourself with all the enemy locations in Fantasy Life i: The Girl Who Steals Time .

All Enemy Locations in Fantasy Life i

There are 126 monsters in Fantasy Life i: The Girl Who Steals Time . Some enemies only appear in Treasure Groves, some only show up in Ginormosia, and others can be found everywhere.

This page will be updated as more Ginormosia spawn locations are discovered for each enemy type.

While most of the standard monsters in Fantasy Life i can be found across the islands of the past, the rarer ones require you to rank up each region of Ginormosia to unlock random legendary spawns. If you want to craft every legendary recipe in Fantasy Life i , you'll need to spend a lot of time in Ginormosia or grinding Treasure Groves to scrounge up the necessary materials.

item.title: Star Wars Battlefront Hopefully Hasn't Faced the Reaper
item.description:
Ever since its inception back in 2004, the Star Wars Battlefront series has been taking players on a wild ride through the galaxy far, far away. They have gotten to experience some of the franchise's most iconic battles, stepped into the shoes of its biggest heroes and villains, and even tried their hand at conquering the galaxy for themselves. It has been fantastic to see, with many never wanting to leave its many battlefields. However, it has been years since the last mainline Star Wars Battlefront launched, and as of now, there is seemingly nothing looming on the horizon.

Just like with the gap between the original Star Wars Battlefront 2 and EA's reboot in 2015, it currently feels like the series is on a bit of a hiatus. Outside of a re-release of the two original games, players really have had nothing else to turn to. While it does not seem like that will be changing anytime soon, it really should. The Star Wars Battlefront brand has led to some fantastic FPS titles, and hopefully, it is given the chance to continue to do just that.

The Star Wars Battlefront Series Needs to Live On

Star Wars Battlefront Has Spawned Some Great FPS Titles

The Star Wars Battlefront series first began back in 2004, and it seemed to be a massive success right away. Players loved being plunged into the galaxy's most iconic battlefields, with the game truly capturing that Star Wars feel. Because of that, Pandemic quickly got to work on the sequel, which would launch only a year later. That sequel would end up taking everything good about that first game and expanding it with so much more Star Wars goodness. That blend would ultimately lead to a game that is still considered by many to be one of the best that the franchise offers.

Outside some smaller-scale spin-offs, it took until 2015 for the next mainline Star Wars Battlefront to hit store shelves. However, unlike its predecessors, this game was locked to the original trilogy and seemed to be lacking in many areas. Luckily, 2017's Star Wars Battlefront 2 would end up rectifying much of that and delivered a pretty strong FPS title. But it would end up being embroiled in much controversy over its microtransaction model, which ultimately held it back. And since its final update in 2020, EA has done nothing with the IP.

It Feels Like a Great Time for Battlefront 3

After the studio removed the microtransactions from Star Wars Battlefront 2 and released a slew of updates, it became a pretty great FPS title. Recently, there has even been a massive resurgence in players, with it actually breaking its Steam concurrent player record. Couple that with the popularity of the IP on a whole, and it seems only natural that a Star Wars Battlefront 3 should hit store shelves at some point. However, it currently seems like there are no plans to deliver something like that.

According to a former DICE employee, Mats Holm, fans shouldn't expect to see a Star Wars Battlefront 3 any time soon, with most of the original Battlefront 2 team no longer with the developer.

A Star Wars Battlefront 3 could be a massively successful title if it is able to hit all the right notes. It needs to adapt the three trilogies, give players substantial amounts of content to fight through, and be free from any sort of microtransaction controversy. If the studio can do all that and deliver an immersive experience, then players would likely flock to it. And as the release date for the next Star Wars film looms, it feels like the perfect time to do just that.

It remains to be seen if EA has any plans for the Star Wars Battlefront brand going forward. If it does not, then hopefully another studio will be able to take it for a spin. The concept is just too good to be left gathering dust, and with the right team, it could lead to something truly special for fans of the galaxy far, far away.
